title: Achaemenid Assyria
summary: Athura[1] (Old Persian: ğ ğ°ğ¢ğ¼ğ  AÎ¸urÄ), also called Assyria, was a geographical area within the Achaemenid Empire in Upper Mesopotamia from 539 to 330 BC as a military protectorate state. Although sometimes regarded as a satrapy,[2][3] Achaemenid royal inscriptions list it as a dahyu (plural dahyÄva), a concept generally interpreted as meaning either a group of people or both a country and its people, without any administrative implication.[4][5][6]
